## 

<span key="e452f0f4af504393a358f94d3dcfcb07"><span offset-key="e452f0f4af504393a358f94d3dcfcb07:0">How to Install Python on Linux</span></span>

<span key="dcaaa376d4f04c8d8422e1bc5c043015"><span offset-key="dcaaa376d4f04c8d8422e1bc5c043015:0">There are two installation methods on Linux:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">1.</span>
    <span key="2b9b7b7c3bad405b862352a7ba8c74b4"><span offset-key="2b9b7b7c3bad405b862352a7ba8c74b4:0">Using your operating system’s package manager</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">2.</span>
    <span key="165becfddf3341f78b2cfaf5c6775fda"><span offset-key="165becfddf3341f78b2cfaf5c6775fda:0">Building Python from source code</span></span>

<span key="46975913f94b44a89c99f5989172b52a"><span offset-key="46975913f94b44a89c99f5989172b52a:0">In this section, you’ll learn how to check which version of Python, if any, is on your Linux computer. You’ll also learn which of the two installation methods you should use.</span></span>

### 

<span key="e9069250cb7b4d739f9f33066ceed25d"><span offset-key="e9069250cb7b4d739f9f33066ceed25d:0">How to Check Your Python Version on Linux</span></span>

<span key="ee33e82ed4f148a39dbdf5d1cebfc107"><span offset-key="ee33e82ed4f148a39dbdf5d1cebfc107:0">Many Linux distributions come packaged with Python, but it probably won’t be the latest version and may even be Python 2 instead of Python 3. You should check the version to make sure.</span></span>

<span key="e03c6ff9ab9d4296a106e2b6feec3101"><span offset-key="e03c6ff9ab9d4296a106e2b6feec3101:0">To find out which version of Python you have, open a terminal window and try the following commands:</span></span>

1

<span key="167aeb70cb8b4f549f2f220fbbe57662"><span offset-key="167aeb70cb8b4f549f2f220fbbe57662:0"># Check the system Python version</span></span>

2

<span key="cb41a94a6dc04dc3a2028e8d94b4dafa"><span offset-key="cb41a94a6dc04dc3a2028e8d94b4dafa:0">$ python --version</span></span>

3

<span key="6aebfb54534e46c5bc5421d53906d001"><span offset-key="6aebfb54534e46c5bc5421d53906d001:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="ee211652d4f34987a22a72c7e49780d4"><span offset-key="ee211652d4f34987a22a72c7e49780d4:0"># Check the Python 2 version</span></span>

5

<span key="c318d920dc074a17a3697f13409ffa04"><span offset-key="c318d920dc074a17a3697f13409ffa04:0">$ python2 --version</span></span>

6

<span key="e4b16844aef74e6abe09089b25a5fb1c"><span offset-key="e4b16844aef74e6abe09089b25a5fb1c:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

7

<span key="c9fbaaf579e6460aa9920b4e517c713c"><span offset-key="c9fbaaf579e6460aa9920b4e517c713c:0"># Check the Python 3 version</span></span>

8

<span key="14de1744e1ff47cbb81de76acc2eefdd"><span offset-key="14de1744e1ff47cbb81de76acc2eefdd:0">$ python3 --version</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f11964d5a2e54e388c40c2d86800e6ec"><span offset-key="f11964d5a2e54e388c40c2d86800e6ec:0">If you have Python on your machine, then one or more of these commands should respond with a version number.</span></span>

<span key="b7bb868cb62a427ca28e21bb47afacfa"><span offset-key="b7bb868cb62a427ca28e21bb47afacfa:0">For example, if you already had Python 3.6.10 on your computer, then the </span>`python3 --version`<span offset-key="b7bb868cb62a427ca28e21bb47afacfa:2"> command would display that version number:</span></span>

1

<span key="96bd34f1762d44f5a670a7a6e25362ea"><span offset-key="96bd34f1762d44f5a670a7a6e25362ea:0">$ python3 --version</span></span>

2

<span key="580f89de19aa4d2ab720257ef266a93e"><span offset-key="580f89de19aa4d2ab720257ef266a93e:0">Python 3.6.10</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="892fcdf15edc4a91895f0309fa3e267a"><span offset-key="892fcdf15edc4a91895f0309fa3e267a:0">You’ll want to get the latest version of Python if your current version is in the Python 2.X series or is not the latest version of Python 3 available, which was 3.8.4 as of this writing.</span></span>

### 

<span key="3e27f8760f2e48178cad791ce77180af"><span offset-key="3e27f8760f2e48178cad791ce77180af:0">What Your Options Are</span></span>

<span key="b7a11d9c7572415e9015cadf81c484db"><span offset-key="b7a11d9c7572415e9015cadf81c484db:0">There are two ways to install the official Python distribution on Linux:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">1.</span>
    <span key="865d1e5c86c74b27a2857b059d95101a">**Install from a package manager:**<span offset-key="865d1e5c86c74b27a2857b059d95101a:1"> This is the most common installation method on most Linux distributions. It involves running a command from the command line.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">2.</span>
    <span key="a928281de9614607b72fa9e64e3074cb">**Build from source code:**<span offset-key="a928281de9614607b72fa9e64e3074cb:1"> This method is more difficult than using a package manager. It involves running a series of commands from the command line as well as making sure you have the correct dependencies installed to compile the Python source code.</span></span>

<span key="670600e829814bf2bacc5181e451b294"><span offset-key="670600e829814bf2bacc5181e451b294:0">Not every Linux distribution has a package manager, and not every package manager has Python in its package repository. Depending on your operating system, building Python from source code might be your only option.</span></span>

<span key="bc62281e27df4da789fc78b492aa5d0c">**Note:**<span offset-key="bc62281e27df4da789fc78b492aa5d0c:1"> You can also complete the installation on Linux using alternative distributions, such as </span></span><a href="https://www.anaconda.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="714d81c9592845f7a25bd9680155f49d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="35773eb05c5c4940baedff0b4a64cceb"><span data-offset-key="35773eb05c5c4940baedff0b4a64cceb:0">Anaconda</span></span></span></a><span key="6edcf474ae4b40e3b389d19972ec9d4f"><span offset-key="6edcf474ae4b40e3b389d19972ec9d4f:0">, but this tutorial covers only official distributions.</span></span>

<span key="1fcba7d6bdee4528ba9175d5001f7d78"><span offset-key="1fcba7d6bdee4528ba9175d5001f7d78:0">Anaconda is a popular platform for doing scientific computing and data science with Python. To learn how to install Anaconda on Linux, check out the </span></span><a href="https://docs.anaconda.com/anaconda/install/linux/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b531c3c27df14ea7beeab41d2c2dbec8" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="92b13570dfed4926bc308b0cf5edd4e6"><span data-offset-key="92b13570dfed4926bc308b0cf5edd4e6:0">Linux installation guide</span></span></span></a><span key="37fb481b87f14ab787acbbdb7ff48fe2"><span offset-key="37fb481b87f14ab787acbbdb7ff48fe2:0"> in the official Anaconda documentation.</span></span>

<span key="3735d534a7e441e0a46f5db5667c19e3"><span offset-key="3735d534a7e441e0a46f5db5667c19e3:0">Which installation method you use mainly boils down to whether your Linux OS has a package manager and whether you need to control the details of the installation.</span></span>

<span key="c8e09f23b2ef47acbfac0158381a12bc">**Linux Installation Recommendations**</span>

<span key="bbf937216da946a18cfc5e80b398f817"><span offset-key="bbf937216da946a18cfc5e80b398f817:0">The most popular way to install Python on Linux is with your operating system’s package manager, which is a good choice for most users. However, depending on your Linux distribution, Python may not be available through a package manager. In this case, you’ll need to build Python from source code.</span></span>

<span key="613d590cca96420dbe088144e9ec238b"><span offset-key="613d590cca96420dbe088144e9ec238b:0">There are three main reasons that you might choose to build Python from source code:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">1.</span>
    <span key="dbfc95cfe305446190ff17325bf9be53"><span offset-key="dbfc95cfe305446190ff17325bf9be53:0">You can’t download Python from your operating system’s package manager.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">2.</span>
    <span key="096af600eaf14a8a9703fb6e9c44dd19"><span offset-key="096af600eaf14a8a9703fb6e9c44dd19:0">You need to control how Python gets compiled, such as when you want to lower the memory footprint on embedded systems.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">3.</span>
    <span key="a6cb3a2462cd45239ca217624bd5eb3c"><span offset-key="a6cb3a2462cd45239ca217624bd5eb3c:0">You want to try out beta versions and release candidates of the latest and greatest version before it’s generally available.</span></span>

<span key="8dcc77db4e804a35ace006e8a32e0be3"><span offset-key="8dcc77db4e804a35ace006e8a32e0be3:0">To complete the installation on your Linux machine, find your Linux distribution below and follow the steps provided.</span></span>

<span key="027d8d6a19f34bacbc0b5e53fc2f9166"><span offset-key="027d8d6a19f34bacbc0b5e53fc2f9166:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://srv.realpython.net/click/14590204085/?c=62098619220&amp;p=58946116052&amp;r=48596" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c93423d4ad7f47b4b3671b8ce8ffa796" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="3b79e615d32e42eb9e4a8118b110ff41"><span data-offset-key="3b79e615d32e42eb9e4a8118b110ff41:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="cf9835c38f574bd19baea286e6376d2c"><span></span></span></span></a>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h r-1vzi8xi" />

<span key="d3a18a0fdc714dd1b7dbd5ae2bee1499"><span offset-key="d3a18a0fdc714dd1b7dbd5ae2bee1499:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span key="c440fdd529bb4ad58ca1050257a0cc0f"><span offset-key="c440fdd529bb4ad58ca1050257a0cc0f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://realpython.com/account/join/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="35a18d8f73864eba94833726f4c8146d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="070a01562ed142e694c15ed2f498b1b3"><span data-offset-key="070a01562ed142e694c15ed2f498b1b3:0"> Remove ads</span></span></span></a><span key="90c07a49e52242c5b2fd692fe5c11fec"><span offset-key="90c07a49e52242c5b2fd692fe5c11fec:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

### 

<span key="9a75199f819c47e2bbbd294678ccf495"><span offset-key="9a75199f819c47e2bbbd294678ccf495:0">How to Install on Ubuntu and Linux Mint</span></span>

<span key="50235d19348540ac9ae2a1abdb860ad1"><span offset-key="50235d19348540ac9ae2a1abdb860ad1:0">In this section, you’ll learn how to install Python using Ubuntu’s </span>`apt`<span offset-key="50235d19348540ac9ae2a1abdb860ad1:2"> package manager. If you’d like to build Python from source code, skip ahead to the </span></span><a href="https://realpython.com/installing-python/#how-to-build-python-from-source-code" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d08117d1ba364235a7ee8db9a5aaf8f3" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="b86479496c054b4e91cadf2e7645b3d8"><span data-offset-key="b86479496c054b4e91cadf2e7645b3d8:0">How to Build Python From Source Code</span></span></span></a><span key="3415d1c68e4645c1a3f0e2f95887ef6a"><span offset-key="3415d1c68e4645c1a3f0e2f95887ef6a:0"> section.</span></span>

<span key="61e3aeb0e2584535a8880b2981843a69">**Note:**<span offset-key="61e3aeb0e2584535a8880b2981843a69:1"> Linux Mint users can skip to the “Linux Mint and Ubuntu 17 and below” section.</span></span>

<span key="d05da7ab4a9f41c6a32bd5f67ee4c01d"><span offset-key="d05da7ab4a9f41c6a32bd5f67ee4c01d:0">Depending on the version of the Ubuntu distribution you run, the process for setting up Python on your system will vary. You can determine your local Ubuntu version by running the following command:</span></span>

1

<span key="fbb8b3adf5ae4f63b34cb172c4585057"><span offset-key="fbb8b3adf5ae4f63b34cb172c4585057:0">$ lsb\_release -a</span></span>

2

<span key="9565eede3315420ebbe4f6361158dc30"><span offset-key="9565eede3315420ebbe4f6361158dc30:0">No LSB modules are available.</span></span>

3

<span key="f9eb790a86b749acb46ea25f00e6fd0c"><span offset-key="f9eb790a86b749acb46ea25f00e6fd0c:0">Distributor ID: Ubuntu</span></span>

4

<span key="9dcde397d3d540b199fc63419fb42e6e"><span offset-key="9dcde397d3d540b199fc63419fb42e6e:0">Description: Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS</span></span>

5

<span key="188b9fe60ed348fe8040bbb574f8e843"><span offset-key="188b9fe60ed348fe8040bbb574f8e843:0">Release: 16.04</span></span>

6

<span key="0d38ad9cc0894c45a175dd398972e861"><span offset-key="0d38ad9cc0894c45a175dd398972e861:0">Codename: xenial</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1cf227a940ac43daa3dfe7a272f23352"><span offset-key="1cf227a940ac43daa3dfe7a272f23352:0">Follow the instructions below that match the version number you see under </span>`Release`<span offset-key="1cf227a940ac43daa3dfe7a272f23352:2"> in the console output:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="832f0b96a21a469996013a452cd76874">**Ubuntu 18.04, Ubuntu 20.04 and above:**<span offset-key="832f0b96a21a469996013a452cd76874:1"> Python 3.8 doesn’t come by default on Ubuntu 18.04 and above, but it is available in the Universe repository. To install version 3.8, open a terminal application and type the following commands:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="00226a617f8748fa89ea055e5467cb4f"><span offset-key="00226a617f8748fa89ea055e5467cb4f:0">$ sudo apt-get update</span></span>

    2

    <span key="f936bc8f5637481baa91bf8b4f7ae0ca"><span offset-key="f936bc8f5637481baa91bf8b4f7ae0ca:0">$ sudo apt-get install python3.8 python3-pip</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

    <span key="2c8b8a6e001340269f4a7485a7036f34"><span offset-key="2c8b8a6e001340269f4a7485a7036f34:0">Once the installation is complete, you can run Python 3.8 with the </span>`python3.8`<span offset-key="2c8b8a6e001340269f4a7485a7036f34:2"> command and </span>`pip`<span offset-key="2c8b8a6e001340269f4a7485a7036f34:4"> with the </span>`pip3`<span offset-key="2c8b8a6e001340269f4a7485a7036f34:6"> command.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="c88ddfb1c4da477dbcd96af959f75f5e">**Linux Mint and Ubuntu 17 and below:**<span offset-key="c88ddfb1c4da477dbcd96af959f75f5e:1"> Python 3.8 isn’t in the Universe repository, so you need to get it from a Personal Package Archive (PPA). For example, to install from the </span></span><a href="https://launchpad.net/~deadsnakes/+archive/ubuntu/ppa" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2e86f19e27f44aa9881aaa94cd9ddd2a" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="810f04b63812404fafa17d87a33a444a"><span data-offset-key="810f04b63812404fafa17d87a33a444a:0">“deadsnakes” PPA</span></span></span></a><span key="88e926dd6e9749d9be95e99c5ed1a43f"><span offset-key="88e926dd6e9749d9be95e99c5ed1a43f:0">, use the following commands:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="57585805c7c34e8e9fcf1e8a86658838"><span offset-key="57585805c7c34e8e9fcf1e8a86658838:0">$ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:deadsnakes/ppa</span></span>

    2

    <span key="c5768bb26d294a0aa0a0e90037e34a48"><span offset-key="c5768bb26d294a0aa0a0e90037e34a48:0">$ sudo apt-get update</span></span>

    3

    <span key="afe0475c372e48b8b520de99f98d1d6d"><span offset-key="afe0475c372e48b8b520de99f98d1d6d:0">$ sudo apt-get install python3.8 python3-pip</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

    <span key="ca39afe09a0d4fc4aaa578cf0670ef28"><span offset-key="ca39afe09a0d4fc4aaa578cf0670ef28:0">Once the installation is complete, you can run Python 3.8 with the </span>`python3.8`<span offset-key="ca39afe09a0d4fc4aaa578cf0670ef28:2"> command and run </span>`pip`<span offset-key="ca39afe09a0d4fc4aaa578cf0670ef28:4"> with the </span>`pip3`<span offset-key="ca39afe09a0d4fc4aaa578cf0670ef28:6"> command.</span></span>

<span key="8529eca624504134995e7a3776b8c454"><span offset-key="8529eca624504134995e7a3776b8c454:0">Congratulations! You now have Python 3 set up on your machine!</span></span>

### 

<span key="5566e608bd354e05ba14dc21942fa966"><span offset-key="5566e608bd354e05ba14dc21942fa966:0">How to Install on Debian Linux</span></span>

<span key="9795d4f26c72493d90065dbdcf43d503"><span offset-key="9795d4f26c72493d90065dbdcf43d503:0">Before you can install Python 3.8 on Debian, you’ll need to install the </span>`sudo`<span offset-key="9795d4f26c72493d90065dbdcf43d503:2"> command. To install it, execute the following commands in a terminal:</span></span>

1

<span key="c0372625ec5a40b6845ed2f4209552b6"><span offset-key="c0372625ec5a40b6845ed2f4209552b6:0">$ su</span></span>

2

<span key="6312ec6109b84f7ab5490b04ab6e7cf6"><span offset-key="6312ec6109b84f7ab5490b04ab6e7cf6:0">$ apt-get install sudo</span></span>

3

<span key="b93e046a68884e9cb4f655acb71bd3a5"><span offset-key="b93e046a68884e9cb4f655acb71bd3a5:0">$ sudo vim /etc/sudoers</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7555d19c0bb043909321602ed8b41f6c"><span offset-key="7555d19c0bb043909321602ed8b41f6c:0">After that, open the </span>`/etc/sudoers`<span offset-key="7555d19c0bb043909321602ed8b41f6c:2"> file using the </span>`sudo vim`<span offset-key="7555d19c0bb043909321602ed8b41f6c:4"> command or your favorite text editor. Add the following line of text to the end of the file, replacing </span>`your_username`<span offset-key="7555d19c0bb043909321602ed8b41f6c:6"> with your actual username:</span></span>

1

<span key="e6732f3022654e38bb7cadc963667d1e"><span offset-key="e6732f3022654e38bb7cadc963667d1e:0">your\_username ALL=(ALL) ALL</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="62dcb283c5174cbfbb49abac948611ae"><span offset-key="62dcb283c5174cbfbb49abac948611ae:0">Now you can skip ahead to the </span></span><a href="https://realpython.com/installing-python/#how-to-build-python-from-source-code" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="28b4644344fb4da0955edd52319a7933" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="8fb0d67cb6364f7eb28c4e83ec056373"><span data-offset-key="8fb0d67cb6364f7eb28c4e83ec056373:0">How to Build Python From Source Code</span></span></span></a><span key="aa579f30aefa4001a40d835fbeb980b6"><span offset-key="aa579f30aefa4001a40d835fbeb980b6:0"> section to finish installing Python.</span></span>

### 

<span key="cc1756e99d6a4b1a8b018de93d2775d4"><span offset-key="cc1756e99d6a4b1a8b018de93d2775d4:0">How to Install on openSUSE</span></span>

<span key="2a6090ba58714433922905c5285384ee"><span offset-key="2a6090ba58714433922905c5285384ee:0">Building from source is the most reliable way to set up Python on openSUSE. To do that, you’ll need to install the development tools, which can be done in </span>`YaST`<span offset-key="2a6090ba58714433922905c5285384ee:2"> via the menus or by using </span>`zypper`<span offset-key="2a6090ba58714433922905c5285384ee:4">:</span></span>

1

<span key="70ebe9a130104082b07eb5fc985912d7"><span offset-key="70ebe9a130104082b07eb5fc985912d7:0">$ sudu zypper install -t pattern devel\_C\_C</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="5fb53f2212db4d46b31561d5427bd34a"><span offset-key="5fb53f2212db4d46b31561d5427bd34a:0">This might take a while to complete as it installs over 150 packages. Once it’s completed, skip ahead to the </span></span><a href="https://realpython.com/installing-python/#how-to-build-python-from-source-code" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="38c6c4e047e14aaa9d66a98d2522b36d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="55a8b8c799bd4197b979a1c7a4cd37d8"><span data-offset-key="55a8b8c799bd4197b979a1c7a4cd37d8:0">How to Build Python From Source Code</span></span></span></a><span key="7aca87a1dea248faa944dbf10a565453"><span offset-key="7aca87a1dea248faa944dbf10a565453:0"> section.</span></span>

### 

<span key="e612bf1c7096491585421ab9bc4f6dc7"><span offset-key="e612bf1c7096491585421ab9bc4f6dc7:0">How to Install on CentOS and Fedora</span></span>

<span key="a42667f6643448dd86719ac0e93f0e40"><span offset-key="a42667f6643448dd86719ac0e93f0e40:0">Python 3.8 isn’t available in the CentOS and Fedora repositories, so you’ll have to build Python from source code. Before you compile Python, though, you need to make sure your system is prepared.</span></span>

<span key="3353f578decd430588d69131994726ca"><span offset-key="3353f578decd430588d69131994726ca:0">First, update the </span></span><a href="http://yum.baseurl.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="eb2192ca5ed04031ab9ce31137e973b6" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="32fb0fbf1ff04345b3ea5d4d283b3d04"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="32fb0fbf1ff04345b3ea5d4d283b3d04:0">yum</code><span data-offset-key="32fb0fbf1ff04345b3ea5d4d283b3d04:1"> package manager</span></span></span></a><span key="126b72f2c46d4deba5a2afa0d89584fe"><span offset-key="126b72f2c46d4deba5a2afa0d89584fe:0">:</span></span>

1

<span key="1c6cef0728bd481aac1047195122f74b"><span offset-key="1c6cef0728bd481aac1047195122f74b:0">$ sudo yum -y update</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="190a989e27284536b4f22ba18be0f741"><span offset-key="190a989e27284536b4f22ba18be0f741:0">Once </span>`yum`<span offset-key="190a989e27284536b4f22ba18be0f741:2"> finishes updating, you can install the necessary build dependencies with the following commands:</span></span>

1

<span key="35dbb334332f42b08a9ea8453c1fe3b3"><span offset-key="35dbb334332f42b08a9ea8453c1fe3b3:0">$ sudo yum -y groupinstall "Development Tools"</span></span>

2

<span key="fc13cd982d4244e4952b9fd9009b1c62"><span offset-key="fc13cd982d4244e4952b9fd9009b1c62:0">$ sudo yum -y install gcc openssl-devel bzip2-devel libffi-devel</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2c041bf919b140048b552b1a70663252"><span offset-key="2c041bf919b140048b552b1a70663252:0">When everything is finished installing, skip ahead to the </span></span><a href="https://realpython.com/installing-python/#how-to-build-python-from-source-code" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b866469621624b20bc7368db23404791" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="af68e0dd71974a6ca405296b4f76515b"><span data-offset-key="af68e0dd71974a6ca405296b4f76515b:0">How to Build Python From Source Code</span></span></span></a><span key="1380ccfff54e4a218a6f91bc1d83df45"><span offset-key="1380ccfff54e4a218a6f91bc1d83df45:0"> section.</span></span>

<span key="a9cd82fe848f4a3383aac603a53972b2"><span offset-key="a9cd82fe848f4a3383aac603a53972b2:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://srv.realpython.net/click/53616533979/?c=62098619220&amp;p=58946116052&amp;r=49638" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3690fa01a5db4e47b45d18d890cc138c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="8b807c5750754301a1195b47da14b2e2"><span data-offset-key="8b807c5750754301a1195b47da14b2e2:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="1dcac0fddb4d419084127f68aedb26c6"><span></span></span></span></a>

### 

<span key="875c23fe167a4e0badaa5888f817650a"><span offset-key="875c23fe167a4e0badaa5888f817650a:0">How to Install on Arch Linux</span></span>

<span key="5f392a21ac054d2db730bc286707cba2"><span offset-key="5f392a21ac054d2db730bc286707cba2:0">Arch Linux is fairly diligent about keeping up with Python releases. It’s likely you already have the latest version. If not, use the following command to update Python:</span></span>

1

<span key="cbe8a83370514b468a32b1ff9b260035"><span offset-key="cbe8a83370514b468a32b1ff9b260035:0">$ packman -S python</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="aff97c7442b6403281a15c934f64cdfb"><span offset-key="aff97c7442b6403281a15c934f64cdfb:0">When Python is finished updating, you should be all set!</span></span>

### 

<span key="cd1477c43d1c4fd4ac3d9d6298c73374"><span offset-key="cd1477c43d1c4fd4ac3d9d6298c73374:0">How to Build Python From Source Code</span></span>

<span key="3e23408285f643a8be246e7d63c484fb"><span offset-key="3e23408285f643a8be246e7d63c484fb:0">Sometimes your Linux distribution doesn’t have the latest version of Python, or maybe you just want to be able to build the latest, greatest version yourself. Here are the steps you need to take to build Python from source:</span></span>

<span key="215752bd96ca4a22bf6854a7d230a7e9">**Step 1: Download the Source Code**</span>

<span key="68e5873578c34c428f3acc4142333fe7"><span offset-key="68e5873578c34c428f3acc4142333fe7:0">To start, you need to get the Python source code. Python.org makes this fairly straightforward. If you go to the </span></span><a href="https://www.python.org/downloads/source/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="5f38843320284199b698a0ebbb8afce9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="352d79e208344b99a7de235d73d39dd3"><span data-offset-key="352d79e208344b99a7de235d73d39dd3:0">Downloads</span></span></span></a><span key="c5e75cc9f32148cebc327529f1181647"><span offset-key="c5e75cc9f32148cebc327529f1181647:0"> page, then you’ll see the latest source for Python 3 at the top. Just make sure you don’t grab Legacy Python, Python 2!</span></span>

<span key="9c8080ce56e149498ac007ac366206aa"><span offset-key="9c8080ce56e149498ac007ac366206aa:0">When you select the Python 3 version, you’ll see a “Files” section at the bottom of the page. Select </span>*Gzipped source tarball*<span offset-key="9c8080ce56e149498ac007ac366206aa:2"> and download it to your machine. If you prefer a command-line method, you can use </span>`wget`<span offset-key="9c8080ce56e149498ac007ac366206aa:4"> to download the file to your current directory:</span></span>

1

<span key="15d7255b52b64472944119af7cd3b53a"><span offset-key="15d7255b52b64472944119af7cd3b53a:0">$ wget https://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.8.4/Python-3.8.4.tgz</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="db530d100a5e4e39a3684f0048012e48"><span offset-key="db530d100a5e4e39a3684f0048012e48:0">When the tarball finishes downloading, there are a few things you’ll need to do to prepare your system for building Python.</span></span>

<span key="897b491fa98b4545b0f395bb5b7ea044">**Step 2: Prepare Your System**</span>

<span key="4579b8ac0f0943c1a266c728b0d91001"><span offset-key="4579b8ac0f0943c1a266c728b0d91001:0">There are a few distro-specific steps involved in building Python from scratch. The goal of each step is the same on all distros, but you might need to translate to your distribution if it doesn’t use </span>`apt-get`<span offset-key="4579b8ac0f0943c1a266c728b0d91001:2">:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">1.</span>
    <span key="abd971230f7e46558425077f15c397e3"><span offset-key="abd971230f7e46558425077f15c397e3:0">First, update your package manager and upgrade your packages:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="dc01c76b12164c7d9b364987d4f97691"><span offset-key="dc01c76b12164c7d9b364987d4f97691:0">$ sudo apt-get update</span></span>

    2

    <span key="f5d6627fad934662bf24373a6b870c6f"><span offset-key="f5d6627fad934662bf24373a6b870c6f:0">$ sudo apt-get upgrade</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">2.</span>
    <span key="fad40a1898d64889b36b09297599a1d6"><span offset-key="fad40a1898d64889b36b09297599a1d6:0">Next, make sure you have all of the build requirements installed:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="170f25d2de484d3fb9c1bc3c3cd0e246"><span offset-key="170f25d2de484d3fb9c1bc3c3cd0e246:0"># For apt-based systems (like Debian, Ubuntu, and Mint)</span></span>

    2

    <span key="605890a4341e4f16b2d32174cb90c1ff"><span offset-key="605890a4341e4f16b2d32174cb90c1ff:0">$ sudo apt-get install -y make build-essential libssl-dev zlib1g-dev \\</span></span>

    3

    <span key="44801227a2c14733a7ce98fb266ab784"><span offset-key="44801227a2c14733a7ce98fb266ab784:0"> libbz2-dev libreadline-dev libsqlite3-dev wget curl llvm \\</span></span>

    4

    <span key="e230b0d767b84552835e51d52261618d"><span offset-key="e230b0d767b84552835e51d52261618d:0"> libncurses5-dev libncursesw5-dev xz-utils tk-dev</span></span>

    5

    <span key="4044e1504bbf447e940d75d9698dbf37"><span offset-key="4044e1504bbf447e940d75d9698dbf37:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

    6

    <span key="a04f8c0c6a1244eeacb5713a5c711bf0"><span offset-key="a04f8c0c6a1244eeacb5713a5c711bf0:0"># For yum-based systems (like CentOS)</span></span>

    7

    <span key="94a6d8bcb1f04162ae60f840bc016164"><span offset-key="94a6d8bcb1f04162ae60f840bc016164:0">$ sudo yum -y groupinstall "Development Tools"</span></span>

    8

    <span key="e913cbcb432b428e956b52d92262b1d3"><span offset-key="e913cbcb432b428e956b52d92262b1d3:0">$ sudo yum -y install gcc openssl-devel bzip2-devel libffi-devel</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

    <span key="6462dc7760ac43f58ab8ae0036a90c9e"><span offset-key="6462dc7760ac43f58ab8ae0036a90c9e:0">It’s fine if you already have some of the requirements installed on your system. You can execute the above commands and any existing packages will not be overwritten.</span></span>

<span key="69bfcc6a57c54c7aa76f3968b5925451"><span offset-key="69bfcc6a57c54c7aa76f3968b5925451:0">Now that your system is ready to go, it’s time to start building Python!</span></span>

<span key="4cc39b57e33746f6a54b4ccd4939f632">**Step 3: Build Python**</span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">1.</span>
    <span key="75b4a8bc9a8545dc82717ddb3adbf7f2"><span offset-key="75b4a8bc9a8545dc82717ddb3adbf7f2:0">Once you have the prerequisites and the TAR file, you can unpack the source into a directory. Note that the following command will create a new directory called </span>`Python-3.8.3`<span offset-key="75b4a8bc9a8545dc82717ddb3adbf7f2:2"> under the one you’re in:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="b5fb5877cd7143349d0371ce98097cfc"><span offset-key="b5fb5877cd7143349d0371ce98097cfc:0">$ tar xvf Python-3.8.4.tgz</span></span>

    2

    <span key="47f6ea7a49cd4c9fa7a50ab29d4943bd"><span offset-key="47f6ea7a49cd4c9fa7a50ab29d4943bd:0">$ cd Python-3.8.4</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">2.</span>
    <span key="7ef4b9d9a87c47a280e2e72b4b5df258"><span offset-key="7ef4b9d9a87c47a280e2e72b4b5df258:0">Now you need to run the </span>`./configure`<span offset-key="7ef4b9d9a87c47a280e2e72b4b5df258:2"> tool to prepare the build:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="65e8cde9213b4e048b7effb0ae965d8e"><span offset-key="65e8cde9213b4e048b7effb0ae965d8e:0">$ ./configure --enable-optimizations --with-ensurepip=install</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

    <span key="cda060a88b8244cf99710e8e20eec74d"><span offset-key="cda060a88b8244cf99710e8e20eec74d:0">The </span>`enable-optimizations`<span offset-key="cda060a88b8244cf99710e8e20eec74d:2"> flag will enable some optimizations within Python to make it run about 10 percent faster. Doing this may add twenty or thirty minutes to the compilation time. The </span>`with-ensurepip=install`<span offset-key="cda060a88b8244cf99710e8e20eec74d:4"> flag will install </span>`pip`<span offset-key="cda060a88b8244cf99710e8e20eec74d:6"> bundled with this installation.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">3.</span>
    <span key="fb370656086a4634a4d20001ad0f78b9"><span offset-key="fb370656086a4634a4d20001ad0f78b9:0">Next, you build Python using </span>`make`<span offset-key="fb370656086a4634a4d20001ad0f78b9:2">. The </span>`-j`<span offset-key="fb370656086a4634a4d20001ad0f78b9:4"> option simply tells </span>`make`<span offset-key="fb370656086a4634a4d20001ad0f78b9:6"> to split the building into parallel steps to speed up the compilation. Even with the parallel builds, this step can take several minutes:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="93ea0f40d2a44b1ebda23d0e6832ada2"><span offset-key="93ea0f40d2a44b1ebda23d0e6832ada2:0">$ make -j 8</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height: 24px">4.</span>
    <span key="f889250d8647482dbe593c5c38fd1128"><span offset-key="f889250d8647482dbe593c5c38fd1128:0">Finally, you’ll want to install your new version of Python. You’ll use the </span>`altinstall`<span offset-key="f889250d8647482dbe593c5c38fd1128:2"> target here to avoid overwriting the system Python. Since you’re installing into </span>`/usr/bin`<span offset-key="f889250d8647482dbe593c5c38fd1128:4">, you’ll need to run as root:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="8ee0bef9189140a28f4b283b6bff2953"><span offset-key="8ee0bef9189140a28f4b283b6bff2953:0">$ sudo make altinstall</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

<span key="3de89a6b581f4254b2179ceb5b18ced4"><span offset-key="3de89a6b581f4254b2179ceb5b18ced4:0">It might take a while to finish installation. Once it’s done, you can verify that Python is set up correctly.</span></span>

<span key="7e2dd7748ae54834a325a40e486ef33c">**Step 4: Verify Your Installation**</span>

<span key="1e958c1db2e24dfbb32ab3d3c02be630"><span offset-key="1e958c1db2e24dfbb32ab3d3c02be630:0">Test that the </span>`python3.8 --version`<span offset-key="1e958c1db2e24dfbb32ab3d3c02be630:2"> command returns the latest version:</span></span>

1

<span key="a2a8f016c89c4e7b93e2fe7bf5a619eb"><span offset-key="a2a8f016c89c4e7b93e2fe7bf5a619eb:0">$ python3.8 --version</span></span>

2

<span key="02fdb60bfbc44c4d98869d462d808598"><span offset-key="02fdb60bfbc44c4d98869d462d808598:0">Python 3.8.4</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4ae72f30cbae4f2d9db1b48a707a9536"><span offset-key="4ae72f30cbae4f2d9db1b48a707a9536:0">If you see </span>`Python 3.8.4`<span offset-key="4ae72f30cbae4f2d9db1b48a707a9536:2">, then you’re all set!</span></span>

<span key="1c81c2484cb544288e3145205f9c356c"><span offset-key="1c81c2484cb544288e3145205f9c356c:0">If you have some extra time on your hands, you can also run the </span></span><a href="https://devguide.python.org/runtests/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="26ef08fbed21439392cde3fbad65bae2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-3040_262-3041-240__"><span data-key="8964ff336c0f43c38d0bed7f0acda24f"><span data-offset-key="8964ff336c0f43c38d0bed7f0acda24f:0">test suite</span></span></span></a><span key="987f636e89884c2f9f598cc3ff6fa594"><span offset-key="987f636e89884c2f9f598cc3ff6fa594:0"> to make sure everything is working properly on your system.</span></span>

<span key="ddf65af6213446eaab48fc112a771b81"><span offset-key="ddf65af6213446eaab48fc112a771b81:0">To run the test suite, type the following command:</span></span>

1

<span key="689a8ff5899e486a84c6ca467d45761f"><span offset-key="689a8ff5899e486a84c6ca467d45761f:0">$ python3.8 -m test</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="af0cfeddd6494b57bc0bfcb71d707f0a"><span offset-key="af0cfeddd6494b57bc0bfcb71d707f0a:0">You’ll probably want to find something else to do for a while, as your computer will be running tests for some time. If all the tests pass, then you can be confident that your brand-new Python build is working as expected!</span></span>

<span key="30b81d0d76c44097a6dbc01e161ea709"><span offset-key="30b81d0d76c44097a6dbc01e161ea709:0">\\</span></span>

How to Install Python on Linux
